questions.question: What is the mutation seen in Sickle cell anemia? → Val (6) → Arg → Lysine → Gly (9)
questions.explanation: → Val (6) Correct Answer: A) Glu → Val (6) Explanation: Sickle cell anemia is a genetic disorder caused by a missense mutation in the β -globin gene. This mutation replaces the normal glutamic acid (Glu) at position 6 of the β -globin chain with valine (Val). This Glu → Val substitution leads to the formation of hemoglobin S (HbS), which tends to polymerize when deoxygenated, causing the red blood cells to become sickle-shaped. These sickle-shaped cells are rigid and prone to breaking, leading to anemia and other complications. Pathophysiology of Sickle cell anemia HbS Polymerisation: A single-nucleotide polymorphism in the β -globin gene results in the substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the sixth position in the β -globin chain. This mutation leads to the formation of mutated hemoglobin (HbS). After deoxygenation, HbS molecules polymerize to form bundles. These polymer bundles cause erythrocytes to adopt a sickle shape and also promote hemolysis of erythrocyte, releasing cell-free Hb into circulation. Vaso-occlusion: Sickled erythrocytes impair blood flow and aggregate with neutrophils, platelets, and endothelial cells, causing stasis. Leads to ischemia-reperfusion (I-R) injury. Endothelial Dysfunction: Oxygenated Hb (Fe² I ) depletes endothelial nitric oxide (NO), forming nitrate (NO II ) and methemoglobin (Fe³ I ). Free radicals are generated by NADPH oxidase, xanthine oxidase (XO), and uncoupled endothelial NO synthase (eNOS) contribute to endothelial damage and dysfunction. Methemoglobin (Fe³ I ) breaks down, releasing cell-free heme, which is a major erythrocyte damage-associated molecular pattern (DAMP). Sterile Inflammation: Cell-free heme or ischemia-reperfusion injury triggers sterile inflammation by: Generating reactive oxygen species (ROS). Activating Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4). Inducing neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs). Releasing DAMPs, DNA, and other unidentified factors. This activates the inflammasome pathway, releasing IL-1 β . Sterile inflammation enhances the adhesiveness of neutrophils, platelets, and endothelial cells. This creates a cycle that promotes further vaso-occlusion.

questions.question: A girl experiences prolonged menstrual bleeding and has normal platelet count, PT, and aPTT, but an increased bleeding time, which was determined to be due to a deficiency of GpIIb-IIIa after further analysis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia Explanation: In this scenario, the clinical history and laboratory findings are consistent with Glanzmann Thrombasthenia, a congenital platelet disorder characterized by defective platelet aggregation due to a lack of Gp IIb/IIIa receptors (aids in platelet-platelet adhesion). rFVIIa is helpful for patients who are undergoing surgery or are refractory to platelet transfusions as it enhances thrombin generation at the site of vascular injury and can promote hemostasis despite platelet dysfunction. Glanzmann Thrombasthenia Congenital bleeding disorder History of high consanguinity in marriage of the parents Pathology: Autosomal recessive inheritance Mutations involving chromosome 17 Absence of the platelet Gp IIb/IIIa receptor These receptors are essential for platelet aggregation and hemostasis Clinical Features: Lifelong mucocutaneous bleeding episodes Epistaxis is very common in children Gingival bleeds Gastrointestinal bleeding Menorrhagia Investigations: Tests Results aPTT, PT, and ristocetin cofactor activity Normal Bleeding time Increased Light transmission aggregometry (LTA) (gold standard test) Altered platelet aggregation with ADP, collagen, and epinephrine. Normal aggregation with ristocetin. Flow cytometry Defective expression of alpha IIb beta 3 integrin Molecular genetic tests Gene mutations in ITGA2B or ITGB3 Treatment: Therapy Clinical setting Desmopressin Mild bleeding Platelets and/or recombinant activated clotting factor VII (rFVIIa) Surgery prophylaxis Tranexamic acid Mucocutaneous bleeding Recombinant FVIIa Platelet refractoriness cases Platelet transfusions have the risk of alloimmunization. So, HLA-matched single donor platelets for transfusion are preferred. Bernard-Soulier syndrome (BSS) (Option A), also referred to as Hemorrhagiparous Thrombolytic Dystrophy, is a rare genetic bleeding disorder marked by the presence of abnormally large platelets, a low platelet count (thrombocytopenia), and extended bleeding time. It usually presents at birth and continues throughout life. Hemophilia A (Option C): Severe haemophilia typically presents in the first few months of life, while mild or moderate forms are usually detected later in childhood or adolescence, often incidentally or after trauma, with two-thirds of cases confirmed shortly after the birth of an affected son to a carrier mother. The aPTT is abnormally elevated with a normal PT. Not all individuals with von Willebrand disease (Option D) experience clinically significant bleeding issues, leading many cases to go undiagnosed. In the coagulation profile, aPTT may be prolonged and PT is normal. The von Willebrand factor Reference: Glanzmann Thrombasthenia - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page: 908, 909. questions.question: A 30-year-old female with a history of recurrent headaches presented for further evaluation. On further workup, haemoglobin and total WBC count were normal, while an elevated platelet count was seen. Bone marrow aspiration showed increased megakaryocytes and a JAK2 mutation. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Essential thrombocytosis Explanation: The high platelet count and JAK 2 mutation with increased megakaryocytes in the bone marrow aspiration point to the diagnosis of essential thrombocythemia. Essential Thrombocythemia (ET) This is a type of myeloproliferative neoplasm. Aetiology: Caused by mutations in JAK2, CALR, or MPL genes, known as "driver mutations." Other mutations associated: SH2B3, TP53, IDH2, 20q-, etc. Pathophysiology: JAK2V617F mutation (valine to phenylalanine) activates hematopoietic cytokine receptors, leading to myeloproliferation. CALR mutations result in abnormal protein, affecting cellular proliferation and differentiation. MPL mutations affect thrombopoietin receptor function, increasing thrombocytosis risk. Extreme thrombocytosis (>1 million platelets) can lead to bleeding episodes due to acquired von Willebrand disease. Symptoms & Risks: Characterized by high platelet count and megakaryocytic hyperplasia in bone marrow. Risks include thrombosis, haemorrhage, and potential progression to myelofibrosis or leukemic transformation. Diagnosis: Platelet count >450,000 and presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation. Bone marrow examination may show megakaryocytic hyperplasia. Management: Cytoreduction may be necessary to manage thrombocytosis and prevent complications like thrombosis. Regular monitoring of platelet count and mutation status is key for management. Polycythemia vera (Option A) is a myeloproliferative disorder and patients have uncontrolled RBC production. These patients may have raised WBC and platelets due to stimulation of megakaryocyte and myeloid lineages but the most definite feature is the elevated RBC mass. Primary myelofibrosis (Option C): This is a myeloproliferative neoplasm leading to the deposition of fibrous connective tissue in the bone marrow resulting in bone marrow failure. Chronic myelogenous leukaemia (Option D): Characterized by the presence of the BCR-ABL1 gene, it is a type of myeloproliferative disorder mainly involving the overproduction of granulocytes. It is defined by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, which results from a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 (t(9;22)(q34;q11.2)). Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539709/

questions.question: A 68-year-old male came to the physician with complaints of chronic back pain, easy fatigability and a history of multiple urinary tract infections in the last 3 months. His ESR is elevated, and an x-ray of his skull is shown below. Which of the following investigations is useful for diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Serum electrophoresis Explanation: The clinical features of chronic back pain, easy fatigability, and the x-ray skull features depict multiple myeloma Investigations of Multiple myeloma Hematological Analysis: It may reveal anaemia; ESR is usually elevated. Rare cases of plasma cell leukaemia with high plasma cell counts >2000 plasma cells/ µ L. Serum calcium and urea nitrogen may be elevated. Serum alkaline phosphatase is usually normal. Peripheral smear : Rouleaux formation A/G ratio: Decreased Increased level of β 2 microglobulin. Decreased albumin Renal function test: Increased serum creatinine and uric acid. Imaging: Chest and bone radiographs: Lytic lesions/diffuse osteopenia MRI: Extent of bone marrow infiltration and cord or root compression in patients with pain syndrome PET/CT: Assess bone damage, extramedullary sites of the disease Serum or urine electrophoresis: M spike M spikes are monoclonal immunoglobulins The presence of the M spike

questions.question: A ten-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with fever and swelling of his hands after playing football. He gives a history of previous episodes of swelling of his hands. On imaging, his spleen was found to be shrunken. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Sickle cell anaemia Explanation: The clinical scenario of a child with fever, recurrent swelling of the hands, and a shrunken spleen is consistent with the diagnosis of sickle cell anemia. Clinical Features of Sickle Cell Anemia: Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) persists up to 6 months of life, with a residual amount (<1%) in adulthood. In regions without newborn screening, affected children are typically identified after 6 months of age. Sickle cell disease does not predispose to neonatal jaundice. Fever: Autosplenectomy , along with reduced splenic function, increases susceptibility to infections from encapsulated bacteria: Pneumococci Meningococci H. influenzae Acute abdominal pain: Occurs during vaso-occlusion or distal tissue ischemia. Constant, non-positional abdominal pain, not aggravated by food, was located in the left upper quadrant and epigastric area. Misdiagnosed as acute pancreatitis or splenic abscess. Bone pain: Sickled cells can obstruct blood flow in blood vessels supplying the bones, leading to inadequate oxygen delivery. Lack of oxygen to bone tissue can cause cell death, leading to a complication called avascular necrosis (AVN). IOC for avascular necrosis: MRI Dactylitis/Hand and foot syndrome: Refers to painful, symmetric swelling of the hands and feet in children with sickle cell disease. It occurs due to infarction of the metacarpals, metatarsals, and phalanges caused by sickled erythrocytes blocking blood vessels. Swelling is followed by hyperemia and subperiosteal new bone formation, visible on radiographs 10-14 days after the swelling subsides. Malaria (Option B): While malaria can cause splenomegaly (enlarged spleen) due to the sequestration of parasitized red blood cells, it does not typically lead to splenic atrophy (shrunken spleen). Additionally, recurrent hand swelling is not a characteristic symptom of malaria. Pancreatitis (Option C) refers to inflammation of the pancreas, typically presenting with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. It does not cause symptoms such as fever, hand swelling, or splenic atrophy, which are present in this patient. Measles (Option D) is a viral infection primarily affecting the respiratory system, with characteristic symptoms such as cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and a maculopapular rash. It does not cause splenic atrophy or recurrent hand swelling, making it unlikely in this case. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 758 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9759007/ https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3358402/ https://www.ajol.info/index.php/nhp/article/view/119295# https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6952462/# https://www.cdc.gov/sickle-cell/complications/avascular-necrosis.html https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537007/# https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4621170/

questions.question: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome Explanation: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome X-linked recessive Caused by mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23 that encodes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP) Pathology: Mutations in the WASP gene affect T lymphocytes and other lymphocyte subsets, i.e. dendritic cells, and platelets WASp regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus plays an important role in many lymphocyte functions, including cell adhesion and migration and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting and target cell.s Clinical Triad: Immunodeficiency, thrombocytopenia, and eczema. Clinical manifestation: Recurrent bacterial infections Eczema Bleeding Associated with IBD - Colitis Increased risk of development of malignant lymphoma Investigation: IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are usually normal. Paradoxically the levels of IgA and IgE are often elevated Blood smear: Thrombocytopenia , reduced-sized platelets, impaired platelet aggregation. Diagnosis is made by expression of intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASp) in blood cells. There is defective or absent WAS protein. Treatment: Prophylactic antibiotics Immunoglobulin G (IgG) supplementation Topical treatment of eczema Chediak-Higashi syndrome (Option B) (CHS) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by recurrent pyogenic infections, partial oculocutaneous albinism, neurologic abnormalities, and thrombocytopenia. However, eczema is not a feature of CHS. Thrombocytopenia-absent radius syndrome (Option B) (TAR syndrome) is characterized by severe thrombocytopenia at birth and the absence of the radius bone in the forearm, with thumbs typically present. Eczema is not part of the presentation in TAR syndrome. Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome (Option D) involves oculocutaneous albinism, platelet dysfunction causing bleeding, pulmonary fibrosis, and granulomatous colitis. While thrombocytopenia and recurrent infections may occur, eczema is not a characteristic of this syndrome. Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 842, 907, 2472, 2716 Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis Of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 246 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539838/#

questions.question: For hairy cell leukemia, which drug is considered the preferred choice?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cladribine Explanation: Cladribine (also known as 2-chlorodeoxyadenosine or 2-CdA) is a purine analog chemotherapy drug that has shown high efficacy in the treatment of hairy cell leukemia. It is considered the drug of choice because it achieves high response rates and durable remissions in most patients. Deoxycoformycin is also shown to have a good remission rate. Hairy cell leukemia Mutations BRAF V600E Pathogenesis Mutation of BRAF V600E gene → Activation of the BRAF protein → MAPK/ERK signalling pathway → Uncontrolled proliferation and survival of mature B-cells (Hairy cells). Clinical Presentation Presents with fatigue, recurrent infections, easy bruising, and symptoms related to splenomegaly (e.g., early satiety, abdominal discomfort), pancytopenia Peripheral Blood Findings Hairy cells with round, oblong, or reniform nuclei and pale blue cytoplasm. Bone Marrow Biopsy Findings Hypocellular or fibrotic marrow with "hairy cells". Fried egg appearance. Diagnosis Flow cytometry Immunophenotyping Genetic testing for BRAF V600E mutation Treatment Splenectomy : Often leads to prolonged remission. Nucleosides (Cladribine, Deoxycoformycin) : Highly effective but cause immunosuppression; Interferon- α (Option D): Effective but less so than nucleosides. Vemurafenib (Option B) (BRAF inhibitor) : Used in chemotherapy-refractory cases; not curative but maintains response with chronic use. Vemurafenib + Rituximab (Option A) : Leads to more durable remissions. Prognosis Excellent While rituximab has shown efficacy in the treatment of various B-cell lymphomas, it is not the drug of choice for hairy cell leukemia. Cladribine is the preferred treatment for HCL. Vemurafenib is a targeted therapy drug primarily used for the treatment of certain forms of metastatic melanoma with BRAF V600E mutation. Interferon-alpha is a type of immunotherapy that has been used in the treatment of hairy cell leukemia in the past. It is now less commonly used.

questions.question: A 65-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department with symptoms of breathlessness anemia and severe bone pain. On evaluation a hemoglobin level was found to be 5.4 g/dl, urea level of 86 mg/dl, creatinine level of 6 mg/dl, calcium level of 12, and potassium level of 4.4 and the bone marrow aspiration revealed over 60% of plasma cells. Which of the following could be the appropriate next course of action for the management of this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Dexamethasone + fluids Explanation: Clinical and laboratory features of CRAB (hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anemia, and bone lesions) and >10% clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow, point towards the diagnosis of Multiple myeloma. The next line of management for this typically involves initiating treatment with a combination of dexamethasone (corticosteroid) and fluids. Investigations of Multiple myeloma: Hematological Analysis: It may reveal anemia; ESR is usually elevated. Rare cases of plasma cell leukemia with high plasma cell counts >2000 plasma cells/ µ L. Serum calcium and urea may be elevated. Serum alkaline phosphatase is usually normal. Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation A/G ratio: Decreased Increased level of β 2 microglobulin. Decreased albumin Renal function test: Increased serum creatinine and uric acid. Imaging: Chest and bone radiographs: Lytic lesions/diffuse osteopenia MRI: Extent of bone marrow infiltration and cord or root compression in patients with pain syndrome PET/CT: Assess bone damage, extramedullary sites of the disease Anion gap: (Na+ + K+) – (Cl- + HCO3-): Decreased Serum or urine electrophoresis: M spike Serum light chain assay: Increased Immunofixation: Detects subtypes of light chain. 24-hour urine specimen: Bence Jones protein (serum-free light chains) excretion Fat pad biopsy: To detect amyloid deposits Flow cytometry: CD 138+ (bone marrow plasma cells) FISH: Done to detect chromosomal abnormalities Chromosome 17 deletion and translocation leads to poor prognosis. Bone marrow biopsy: Plasmacytosis >10% Treatment of Multiple Myeloma: Induction Phase: Drugs used: Steroids: Dexamethasone/Prednisolone Immunomodulatory agents: Thalidomide/Lenalidomide Proteasome inhibitors: Bortezomib/Carfilzomib Targeted antibodies: Daratumumab (CD 38 Ab) Autologous Stem Cell Transplantation: Involves removal, storage, and reinfusion of the patient’s own stem cells after high-dose myeloablative therapy. Prognosis of Multiple Myeloma: Durie-Salmon staging system (earlier) International Staging System (ISS): Three-stage system to predict survival based on: β 2-microglobulin Albumin levels Dialysis (Option A) is not the immediate next step in the management of the presented case. Dialysis is primarily used in cases of severe renal failure where conservative management measures have failed. Dexamethasone + lenalidomide (an immunomodulatory drug) (Option B) combination is typically included in the treatment regimen for multiple myeloma, but it is not the immediate next step. Bone marrow transplantation (Option D) is a treatment option for multiple myeloma in certain cases, particularly in younger patients or those with high-risk disease, but not the immediate next step.

questions.question: A 62-year-old male patient with heart failure is scheduled for a heart transplant. His renal function test is deranged, and haemoglobin is 6gm%. The physician ordered 2 units of whole blood. Four hours after transfusion, he developed severe respiratory distress. On examination, he is hypoxemic, has tachycardia and his mean arterial pressure is elevated. Which of the following are the best investigations for the above scenario? Chest X-ray Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level Absolute neutrophil count Leucocyte antibodies Platelets
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - 1 and 2 The clinical scenario of an elderly patient with heart failure, deranged renal function, and developing respiratory distress with hypoxia, tachycardia, and elevated mean arterial pressure following a blood transfusion points towards a diagnosis of transfusion- associated circulatory overload (TACO) . The best investigations in the case of TACO are chest X-ray and BNP levels . Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO): Features Occur after transfusion of red blood cells or plasma products in 1% to 8.9% of transfusions. Has become the leading cause of transfusion-related deaths Causes/Risk Factors Older age Renal failure Preexisting fluid overload Cardiac dysfunction Administration of a large volume of blood components Excessive transfusion rate beyond the patient's hemodynamic tolerance. Diagnosis Hypoxia, dyspnea Tachycardia Systolic hypertension Left heart failure Pulmonary edema Increased central venous pressure Elevated brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) Chest X-ray: Bilateral alveolar infiltrates Prevention Identify at-risk patients. Close monitoring and slow transfusion rates, 1 RBC concentrate over 3-4 hours. Diuretics for hemodynamically stable patients with a history of TACO. Treatment Stopping the transfusion Administering oxygen Diuretics Absolute neutrophil count (Option 3) (ANC) measures the number of neutrophils and is used to assess infection or inflammation. However, TACO is a condition caused by fluid overload and not by infection or inflammation, so ANC is not relevant in this case. Leucocyte antibodies (Option 4) are typically used to identify immune reactions related to transfusions, such as Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) or febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions, which are not the primary concern in TACO. Platelets (Option 5): While platelet levels are useful for assessing bleeding or platelet-related disorders, they are not directly relevant in the diagnosis of TACO. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 895 Wintrobe’s Clinical Hematology, 14th Edition, Page 552,572

questions.question: An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. X-ray spine showed osteolytic lesions. Her lab investigations showed the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis? Hb - 6.9g/dl WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count Serum calcium 13mg/dl Creatinine 2.3mg/dl Total protein 9g/dl Albumin 2.4g/dl
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Multiple myeloma The clinical scenario of an elderly woman with confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain, along with hypercalcemia, renal failure (elevated creatinine), anemia, osteolytic lesions (CRAB features), hypoalbuminemia, and elevated total proteins, points towards the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Multiple Myeloma (MM): Malignant disorder characterized by proliferation of a single clone of plasma cells derived from β -cells in the bone marrow. It is the second most common adult hematological malignancy. Most common cancer with skeletal components as its primary site. Investigations of Multiple myeloma: Hematological Analysis: It may reveal anemia ; ESR is usually elevated. Rare cases of plasma cell leukemia with high plasma cell counts >2000 plasma cells/ µ L. Serum calcium and urea nitrogen may be elevated. Serum alkaline phosphatase is usually normal. Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation A/G ratio: Decreased Increased level of β 2 microglobulin. Decreased albumin Renal function test: Increased serum creatinine and uric acid. Imaging: Chest and bone radiographs: Lytic lesions /diffuse osteopenia MRI: Extent of bone marrow infiltration and cord or root compression in patients with pain syndrome PET/CT: Assess bone damage, extramedullary sites of the disease Anion gap: (Na+ + K+) – (Cl- + HCO3-): Decreased Serum or urine electrophoresis: M spike Serum light chain assay: Increased Immunofixation: Detects subtypes of light chain. 24-hour urine specimen: Bence Jones protein (serum-free light chains) excretion Fat pad biopsy: To detect amyloid deposits Flow cytometry: CD 138+ (bone marrow plasma cells) FISH: Done to detect chromosomal abnormalities Chromosome 17 deletion and translocation leads to poor prognosis. Bone marrow biopsy: Plasmacytosis >10% Clinicopathologic diagnosis of multiple myeloma is based on the following: Clonal plasma cells in bone marrow Presence of CRAB criteria (hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anemia and bone lesions) Metastatic breast cancer (Option A): While metastatic breast cancer can involve bones and cause hypercalcemia, the presence of monoclonal gammopathy (elevated total protein) and anemia strongly favors multiple myeloma. Primary hyperparathyroidism (Option C) is typically characterized by hypercalcemia and low phosphorus but does not cause anemia, monoclonal gammopathy, hypoalbuminemia, or osteolytic bone lesions. Milk-alkali syndrome (Option D) arises from excessive intake of calcium and alkali (often in the form of calcium supplements or vitamin D). It results in hypercalcemia, alkalosis, nephrocalcinosis, and nephrolithiasis, none of which are evident in this patient. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 871,872 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 967 Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 609 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6650180/ https://journals.lww.com/jasn/fulltext/2022/11001/hyperuricemia_and_kidney_function_in_patients.2257.aspx

questions.question: Which of the following interfere with iron absorption?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Phytates Explanation: Phytates are naturally occurring compounds found in certain plant foods such as whole grains, legumes, and nuts . These compounds have the ability to bind to iron and form insoluble complexes in the digestive tract, significantly reducing iron absorption and bioavailability. Factors Increasing Iron Absorption Factors Decreasing Iron Absorption Acidic stomach environment Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) (Option A Ruled Out) Empty stomach Meat proteins Citric acid Haem iron sources (meat, fish) Fermented foods Iron deficiency state Reduced stomach acid Proton pump inhibitors Antacids Tetracycline (chelates iron) Phytates (Option B) (in cereals, legumes) Tea and coffee (tannins) Calcium-rich foods High fiber meals Vitamin C (Option A): Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, enhances iron absorption rather than interfering with it. It helps in the conversion of non-heme iron (the form of iron found in plant-based foods) to a more absorbable form. Oxalate (Option C): Oxalate, found in certain foods like spinach, rhubarb, and beet greens, can affect calcium absorption, but it does not affect iron absorption. While oxalates can bind to minerals, their primary impact is on calcium rather than iron metabolism. Myoglobin (Option D): Myoglobin is a protein found in muscle tissue that stores oxygen and is found in food such as meat. While myoglobin does contain iron, it is not involved in the absorption of iron from the diet. Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37965925/#:~:text=Different%20components%20in%20food%20can,a nd%20polyphenols%20reduce%20iron%20absorption . Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 748, 749

questions.question: What is the interpretation of elevated serum Calcium levels in a patient with normal serum alkaline phosphatase, PTH, and Vitamin D3 levels?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Multiple myeloma Explanation: Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell disorder characterized by the excessive production of monoclonal immunoglobulins (M-protein) . In multiple myeloma, serum calcium levels can be elevated while SAP, PTH, and vitamin D3 levels remain normal . This occurs due to osteolytic lesions and release of calcium from damaged bone tissue due to increased osteoclast activity stimulated by cytokines produced by malignant plasma cells. The normal SAP levels in multiple myeloma help distinguish it from other bone disorders, as SAP is typically elevated in conditions with increased osteoblastic activity . In multiple myeloma, the predominant process is osteolytic rather than osteoblastic , hence SAP remains normal despite bone involvement. Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple Myeloma Presence of clonal bone marrow plasma cells or biopsy-proven bony/extramedullary plasmacytoma and anyone or more of the following myeloma-defining events: Evidence of one or more indicators of end-organ damage attributed to the plasma cell disorder, specifically: (CRAB) Hypercalcemia : Serum calcium >0.25 mmol/L above the upper limit of normal or >2.75 mmol/L (>11 mg/dL) . PTH levels, Vit-D levels are normal Renal Insufficiency : Creatinine clearance <40 mL/min or serum creatinine >177 µ mol/L (>2 mg/dL) . Anemia : Hemoglobin >20 g/L below the lower limit of normal or haemoglobin <100 g/L or <10g/100ml . Bone Lesions : One or more osteolytic lesions identified on skeletal radiography, CT, or PET-CT. Biomarkers of Malignancy (any one of the following) : Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥ 60%. Involved: uninvolved serum-free light chain ratio ≥ 100. 1 focal lesion on MRI studies. Serum markers: Hypercalcemia, ↑ β 2 microglobulin Vitamin D intoxication (Option A): In vitamin D intoxication, both serum calcium and vitamin D3 levels are typically elevated. Additionally, PTH levels are usually suppressed due to the negative feedback mechanism between vitamin D and PTH. Since vitamin D3 levels are normal in this case, vitamin D intoxication can be ruled out. Hyperparathyroidism (Option B): Hyperparathyroidism is characterized by increased PTH levels, which stimulate the release of calcium from bone, resulting in elevated serum calcium levels. In this case, since PTH levels are normal, hyperparathyroidism is not the likely diagnosis. Nutritional rickets (Option D): This option is incorrect as nutritional rickets is a condition caused by a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. In rickets, serum calcium levels would typically be decreased rather than elevated. Additionally, vitamin D levels would be low, which is not the case here. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 871

questions.question: Which of the following investigations should be conducted in a 7-month-old child who has a hemoglobin level of 6.3, a history of recurrent blood transfusions, an MCV of 70 fl, normal MCH, normal MCHC, and a peripheral smear indicating a hypochromic microcytic image?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Hb electrophoresis Explanation: The above child is most probably suffering from thalassemia. The next best step is to get Hb electrophoresis done for confirmation of diagnosis. In Thalassemia, Hb electrophoresis indicates elevated levels of HbF and HbA2. It is best for identifying thalassemia minor HbA2: >3%. Hb electrophoresis Hemoglobin At Birth (1st day) At Adult (6 months) HbF (Fetal Hemoglobin) 95% 2% HbA (Adult Hemoglobin) 2% 95% ( α 2 β 2) HbA2 3% 3% Serum iron (Option A) is measured to check for iron overload due to repeated blood transfusions and is not the next best step. Direct coomb’s test (Option B) is for autoimmune haemolytic anemia and not for thalassemia. Osmotic fragility test (Option C) is done for hereditary spherocytosis. Reference: Harrison's Textbook for Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 436

questions.question: What is the diagnosis of a 50-year-old man who presents with symptoms of anemia, fever, and recurrent nosebleeds? The patient has hepatosplenomegaly and lab investigations indicate a hemoglobin level of 6g/dL, a total leukocyte count of 40,000/cu.mm with 10% blasts, and a platelet count of 12,000/cu.mm. Further investigation reveals the presence of t(8;21) in the blasts.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Acute myeloblastic leukemia Explanation: The diagnosis for this patient is Acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML) as it has clinical and laboratory features consistent with AML and chromosomal translocation of t(8;21). AML is the most common type of acute leukaemia in adults and is typically seen in the elderly. When symptomatic, clinical features are those of pancytopenia. The diagnosis is clinched by bone marrow showing >20% myeloblasts. Emergencies include hyperleukocytosis, neurologic involvement, and DIC. Aetiology of AML: Idiopathic 25-50% cases Bone Marrow Failure Fanconi Anemia Diamond-Blackfan Syndrome Diamond-Blackfan Anemia (DBA) is a rare inherited form of macrocytic anemia characterised by a failure of erythropoiesis in the bone marrow. Shwachman-Diamond Syndrome: An autosomal recessive disorder involving exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. Defective DNA Repair Bloom Syndrome Ataxia Telangiectasia Down Syndrome AML is associated with Down syndrome, particularly the subtype known as Acute Megakaryoblastic Leukemia (AML M7), which involves the GATA1 gene. Exposure to Anticancer Drugs Alkylating agents -> Monosomy 5 & 7 -> AML (After 4-6 years). Anticancer drugs (Topoisomerase 2 inhibitors) -> Chromosome 11 involvement -> AML (After 1-3 years). Radiation Exposure Exposure to radiation, benzene, phenylbutazone, and chloramphenicol may increase the risk of developing AML and bone marrow failure. t(15:17) Chromosomal translocation results in the PML-RARA fusion gene, which is associated with acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APL), a subtype of AML. t(8:21) Chromosomal translocation (RUNX1- RUNX1T1) is associated with myeloid sarcoma. Inversion 16 or t(16;16). - Work up of AML: Blast concentration <20% in peripheral blood/bone marrow aspiration. Decreased Hb Decreased platelet count Decreased TLC initially ALL (Option A) is the most common childhood leukaemia having symptoms such as fever, night sweats, unexplained weight loss painless lymphadenopathy bone pain which are not present here. Pre-leukaemia (Option C) Is a myelodysplastic syndrome Aleukemic leukaemia (Option D) Is a rare type of leukaemia in which the leucocyte count is normal or to the lower side. questions.question: A young woman presents with recurrent headaches, easy bruising, and episodes of visual blurring. Her platelet count is elevated, while her red blood cell (RBC) and white blood cell (WBC) counts are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Essential Thrombocytosis Explanation: The clinical manifestations indicate Essential Thrombocytosis , a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by an isolated elevation in platelet count. The patient presents with classic symptoms including headaches , easy bruising , and visual disturbances , along with the key diagnostic finding of elevated platelets with normal RBC and WBC counts . This condition results from abnormal proliferation of megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, leading to excessive platelet production. Essential Thrombocytosis Definition Clonal myeloproliferative disorder Characterized by increased platelet production Abnormal megakaryocyte proliferation Genetics JAK2 V617F mutation (50-60% of cases) CALR mutations (type 1 and 2) MPL mutations Lab Findings Platelet count >450,000/ µ L Increased bone marrow megakaryocytes Normal RBC and WBC Count Clinical Features Often asymptomatic Thrombotic events (arterial > venous) Erythromelalgia Ocular migraines & visual disturbances TIAs Spontaneous bleeding & easy bruising Diagnostic Criteria Platelet count >450,000/ µ L Bone marrow showing megakaryocyte proliferation Not meeting WHO criteria for other myeloid neoplasms Presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation Complications Thrombosis (major cause of morbidity) Hemorrhage (especially with counts >1 million/ µ L) Progression to myelofibrosis Small risk of leukemic transformation Treatment Low-dose aspirin for thrombosis prevention Hydroxyurea for high-risk patients Anagrelide for cytoreduction Plateletpheresis for severe cases Polycythemia Vera (Option B) presents with elevated levels of all three blood cell lines—RBCs, WBCs, and platelets. The normal RBC count in this case makes this diagnosis unlikely. Patients typically present with ruddy complexion, pruritus, and thrombotic complications. Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (Option C) typically shows elevation in granulocytes and often an increase in platelets as well. The presence of normal WBC count makes CML an unlikely diagnosis, as it characteristically presents with marked leukocytosis. Acute Myeloid Leukemia (Option D) typically presents with abnormal levels of blood cells and can show varying counts of WBCs, RBCs, and platelets. The normal blood counts except for platelets make AML less likely, as it usually presents with cytopenias and blast cells in the peripheral blood. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 807-808

questions.question: A female patient presents to the AIIMS emergency department with severe fatigue. She is a known case of chronic stable angina. While collecting a blood sample, you notice the blood has a brownish hue. What is the underlying diagnosis?
questions.explanation: which there is an increased level of methemoglobin , a form of hemoglobin that is unable to bind and transport oxygen effectively. The blood sample has a characteristic brownish hue on examination. As the patient has a known case of chronic stable angina, it is likely that she is on nitrates, and methemoglobinemia is a side effect of nitrate. Carboxyhemoglobinemia (Option A) results from carbon monoxide poisoning , where CO binds to hemoglobin with high affinity, reducing oxygen delivery. Patients present with cherry-red skin, headache, confusion, and severe hypoxia, but blood appears bright red, not brown . Sideroblastic anemia (Option B) is a disorder of heme synthesis , often associated with iron overload and ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow , leading to microcytic anemia . It does not cause brown-colored blood. Sulfhemoglobinemia (Option D) is caused by sulfur-containing drugs (e.g., sulfonamides, metoclopramide) , leading to irreversible oxidation of hemoglobin and presenting with greenish/bluish blood and cyanosis , which, unlike methemoglobinemia, does not respond to methylene blue . Reference: Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine, 21 st edition, Page 765, 767

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Renal failure Explanation: Renal failure, while it can occur as a consequence of microvascular injury in TTP, is not a defining feature of the disease. Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP) is a rare hematological disorder characterized by: Thrombocytopenia (Option A) Thrombosis (Option B) Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (Option C) TTP vs HUS Feature Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP) Hemolytic-Uremic Syndrome (HUS) Etiology Deficiency or antibodies to ADAMTS13 leading to platelet aggregation Diarrhea associated with E. coli O157:H7 or shigella Features Pentad 1. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) 2. Thrombocytopenia (severe) 3. Renal failure, 4. Neurologic findings 5. Fever Triad 1. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) 2. Thrombocytopenia 3. Renal failure Age Group More common in adults More common in children Association Often women , especially those with HIV or during pregnancy Preceded by diarrhea , especially hemorrhagic diarrhea Renal Failure Not a predominant feature Renal failure is a hallmark, especially in children ADAMTS13 Activity <10% ADAMTS13 activity is diagnostic ADAMTS13 activity is normal, except in rare cases (Atypical HUS) Common Precipitating Factors Idiopathic Infections (HIV) Medications (Ticlopidine, Cyclosporine) Pregnancy Often follows GI infections Atypical HUS has genetic/ complement involvement Treatment Plasma exchange (mainstay) Glucocorticoids Supportive care Dialysis (in severe cases) Relapse Rate 25-45% relapse Relapses can occur, but less frequent than TTP Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Pages 907, 908.

questions.question: In hemolytic anemia, which of the following statements are true? Indirect Van den Bergh test is positive. Serum conjugated bilirubin is raised. Serum transaminases are raised. Urobilinogen is high. GGT is elevated.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1, 4 Explanation: In hemolytic anemia, excessive destruction of red blood cells leads to the following changes Indirect Van den Bergh test is positive (1): Hemolysis causes increased levels of unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin. The indirect Van den Bergh test measures this rise, making it a hallmark of hemolytic anemia. Urobilinogen is high (4): Increased hemoglobin breakdown leads to more bilirubin being converted into urobilinogen in the intestines, resulting in elevated urinary urobilinogen. Serum conjugated bilirubin is raised (2): Hemolysis results in an increase in unconjugated bilirubin, not conjugated bilirubin, which is associated with liver or biliary tract conditions. Serum transaminases are raised (3): Raised transaminases (ALT, AST) are markers of liver damage, not hemolysis. GGT is elevated (5): Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) elevation is specific to liver and biliary tract pathology and is unrelated to hemolysis. Feature Prehepatic Jaundice Hepatic Jaundice Posthepatic (Obstructive) Jaundice Etiology Hemolysis (e.g., hemolytic anemia , malaria) Sickle cell disease G6PD deficiency Liver diseases (e.g., viral hepatitis, cirrhosis, alcoholic liver disease) Liver tumors Drug-induced liver injury Bile duct obstruction (e.g., gallstones, pancreatic cancer, cholangiocarcinoma, strictures, tumors) Mechanism Increased breakdown of red blood cells Excessive bilirubin production Impaired bilirubin conjugation and excretion due to liver dysfunction Blocked bile flow Accumulation of conjugated bilirubin in bloodstream Clinical Features Yellowing of skin and sclera Anemia Fatigue Splenomegaly Yellowing of skin and sclera Fatigue Nausea Hepatomegaly Pruritus Yellowing of skin and sclera Pale stools Dark urine Pruritus Hepatomegaly Bilirubin Elevated unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin Elevated unconjugated and conjugated (direct) bilirubin Elevated conjugated (direct) bilirubin Liver Enzyme Values AST, ALT: Normal or slightly elevated ALP: Normal GGT: Normal AST, ALT: Markedly elevated ALP: Elevated GGT: Elevated AST, ALT: Mildly elevated ALP: Markedly elevated GGT: Elevated Prothrombin time (PT) Normal Prolonged PT Prolonged PT Prolonged PT Urine Normal or slightly dark urine due to excess urobilinogen Dark urine (due to increased conjugated bilirubin) Dark urine (due to conjugated bilirubin) Pale stools (due to reduced bile excretion) Van den Bergh test : Purpose: Differentiates between conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin in serum. Principle: Based on diazotization reaction: Bilirubin reacts with diazotized sulfanilic acid to form a colored complex. Reagents Used: Diazotized sulfanilic acid, methanol (for indirect reaction) Types of Reactions : Reaction Type Findings Bilirubin Type Clinical Significance Direct (Positive within seconds) Immediate pink-red color in aqueous solution Conjugated (Water-soluble) Seen in obstructive jaundice, hepatocellular jaundice Indirect (Delayed or requires methanol) Pink-red color appears only after adding methanol Unconjugated (Water-insoluble) Seen in hemolytic jaundice, Gilbert syndrome, Crigler-Najjar syndrome Biphasic (Both direct and indirect reaction present) Color change seen both in aqueous and after methanol addition Mixed (Conjugated + Unconjugated) Seen in hepatic jaundice (e.g., viral hepatitis, cirrhosis)

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding von Willebrand disease is incorrect?

options.A: Type 2 von Willebrand disease is associated with a moderate bleeding tendency
options.B: Type 3 von Willebrand disease is associated with a complete absence of factor VIII
options.C: Type 1 von Willebrand disease presents with severe bleeding since childhood
options.D: Type 2 von Willebrand disease includes subtypes with varying defects in von Willebrand factor.

questions.explanation: This statement is incorrect. Type 1 von Willebrand disease is the mildest form of the condition and is characterized by a partial deficiency of von Willebrand factor (vWF). Patients typically experience mild bleeding symptoms rather than severe ones. It often presents with mild bleeding tendencies rather than severe, and symptoms may not be apparent until later in life. Incorrect Options: Option A - Type 2 von Willebrand disease is associated with a moderate bleeding tendency: This statement is correct. Type 2 von Willebrand disease is characterized by a qualitative defect in von Willebrand factor, which leads to a moderate bleeding tendency. This type includes several subtypes with different defects in the von Willebrand factor. Option B - Type 3 von Willebrand disease is associated with a complete absence of factor VIII: This statement is partially correct but misleading. Type 3 von Willebrand disease is associated with a severe deficiency or absence of von Willebrand factor, not factor VIII. However, since von Willebrand factor stabilizes factor VIII, the absence of vWF can lead to very low levels of factor VIII. Option D - Type 2 von Willebrand disease includes subtypes with varying defects in von Willebrand factor: This statement is correct. Type 2 von Willebrand disease includes several subtypes (e.g., 2A, 2B, 2M, 2N), each with different defects affecting the function of von Willebrand factor.

questions.question: Which of the following is incorrect regarding myelodysplastic syndrome?

options.B: Treatment-induced MDS is not dependent on age

questions.explanation: than in females. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are true regarding myelodysplastic syndrome. The median age of onset for MDS is around 70 years, making it primarily a disease of the elderly. It can be induced by radiation exposure, either as a part of cancer treatment or from other sources of significant radiation exposure. Treatment-induced MDS is not dependent on age.

questions.question: A 46-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a history of lower back pain and painful urination. Upon investigation, he is found to have normocytic normochromic anemia and hypercalcemia. Serum protein electrophoresis reveals an M-spike in the gamma region. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis of multiple myeloma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Bence Jones protein in urine Explanation: Clinical features of CRAB (hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anemia, and bone lesions), along with the presence of an Gamma region M spike in serum electrophoresis, point towards the diagnosis of Multiple myeloma. Investigations of Multiple myeloma: Hematological Analysis: It may reveal anemia; ESR is usually elevated. Rare cases of plasma cell leukemia with high plasma cell counts >2000 plasma cells/ µ L. Serum calcium and urea nitrogen may be elevated. Serum alkaline phosphatase is usually normal. Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation A/G ratio: Decreased Increased level of β 2 microglobulin. Decreased albumin Renal function test: Increased serum creatinine and uric acid. Imaging: Chest and bone radiographs: Lytic lesions/diffuse osteopenia MRI: Extent of bone marrow infiltration and cord or root compression in patients with pain syndrome PET/CT: Assess bone damage, extramedullary sites of the disease Anion gap: (Na+ + K+) – (Cl- + HCO3-): Decreased Serum or urine electrophoresis: M spike Serum light chain assay: Increased Immunofixation: Detects subtypes of light chain. 24-hour urine specimen: Bence Jones protein (serum-free light chains) excretion Fat pad biopsy: To detect amyloid deposits Flow cytometry: CD 138+ (bone marrow plasma cells) FISH: Done to detect chromosomal abnormalities Chromosome 17 deletion and translocation leads to poor prognosis. Bone marrow biopsy: Plasmacytosis >10% Liver function test (Option A): While liver function tests may be abnormal in some patients with multiple myeloma, they are not specific or diagnostic for the condition. LFTs are more useful in assessing liver involvement or complications. Urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio (Option C): This test assesses kidney function and proteinuria but is not specific for multiple myeloma. While renal function may be affected in myeloma, UACR doesn't detect the characteristic Bence Jones proteins. Heat and acetic acid test (Option D): This is an outdated test that is not used in modern diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Current diagnostic methods are more sensitive and specific. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Pages 867-875

questions.question: A patient presents with symptoms of fatigue, pallor, and weakness. Laboratory tests reveal a low hemoglobin (Hb) level, but the reticulocyte count is normal. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pure Red Cell Aplasia Explanation: Pure Red Cell Aplasia is characterized by a selective deficiency in red blood cell production while other blood cell lines remain normal . The key diagnostic features in this case are the combination of low hemoglobin with a normal reticulocyte count , indicating an inadequate bone marrow response specific to the erythroid lineage. This selective depression of red blood cell production, with preservation of white blood cells and platelets, is the hallmark of PRCA. Pure Red Cell Aplasia Definition A condition characterized by anemia, reticulocytopenia, and absent or rare erythroid precursor cells in bone marrow with normal white cell and platelet production Classification Congenital: Diamond-Blackfan anemia Diagnosed at birth or early childhood Acquired: Thymoma MDS (5s- syndrome) Cancer Autoimmune conditions Viral infections (especially B19 parvovirus) Clinical Associations Thymoma (most frequent) Lymphoid malignancies Autoimmune disorders Chronic lymphocytic leukemia Systemic lupus erythematosus Pregnancy Pathophysiology T-cell mediated immune response Antibodies to erythropoietin Neutralizing antibodies to B19 parvovirus Direct chemical toxicity or immune destruction Treatment General Approach: Identify and treat underlying cause Regular monitoring of hemoglobin levels Supportive care with transfusions Specific Treatments: Immunosuppression (corticosteroids, cyclosporine, ATG, azathioprine) Intravenous immunoglobulin for B19 parvovirus infection Thymectomy if thymoma present Iron chelation as needed Aplastic Anemia (Option A) presents with pancytopenia, affecting all blood cell lines (red cells, white cells, and platelets) due to bone marrow failure. The normal reticulocyte count in this case does not support aplastic anemia, which would show decreased counts across all cell lines. Iron Deficiency Anemia (Option C) typically shows microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells with an elevated reticulocyte count as the bone marrow attempts to compensate for the iron deficiency. The normal reticulocyte count in this scenario makes iron deficiency less likely. Hemolytic Anemia (Option D) is characterized by increased destruction of red blood cells, leading to an elevated reticulocyte count as the bone marrow responds to the increased demand. The normal reticulocyte count in this case does not support ongoing hemolysis. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 798

questions.question: A 26-year-old female presents with menorrhagia and excessive bleeding after a minor surgery. She gave the history of her father and sister having the same bleeding issues and the pattern of inheritance was determined to be autosomal dominant. What is the most likely disorder?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Von Willebrand disease Von Willebrand disease is the most common bleeding disorder with an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. It is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor (vWF), a glycoprotein crucial for platelet adhesion and stabilizing factor VIII in the coagulation cascade. Functions of vWF: Platelet Adhesion: Mediates binding of platelets to subendothelial collagen at sites of vascular injury. Stabilization of Factor VIII: Protects Factor VIII from degradation, prolonging its half-life. Clinical manifestation: Superficial bruising, epistaxis, menorrhagia and gastrointestinal haemorrhage Excessive haemorrhage might only be observed after trauma or surgery Heavy menstrual bleeding Might first manifest with dental extractions, particularly wisdom tooth extraction, or tonsillectomy Investigation: Types aPTT vWF antigen vWF activity FVIII activity Multimer Inheritance 1 Normal or ↑ ↓ ↓ ↓ Normal distribution, decreased in quantity Autosomal dominant 2A Normal or ↑ ↓ ↓↓ ↓ Loss of high- and intermediate-MW multimers Autosomal dominant 2B Normal or ↑ ↓ ↓↓ ↓ Loss of high-MW multimers Autosomal dominant 2M Normal or ↑ ↓ ↓↓ ↓ Normal distribution, decreased in quantity Autosomal dominant 2N ↑↑ Normal or ↓ Normal or ↓ ↓↓ Normal distribution Autosomal recessive 3 ↑↑ ↓↓ ↓↓ ↓↓ Absent Autosomal recessive In general, increase in aPTT and BT, but normal PT and platelet count. (Option A) Treatment: Desmopressin (DDAVP) Tranexamic acid or epsilon-aminocaproic acid for mucosal bleeding or non-serious bleeding Factor VIII concentrates are given to manage serious or persistent bleeding Bleeding in type 3 patients responds only to factor VIII/vWF concentrate Hemophilia A (Option B) and Christmas Disease (Option C) have X-linked recessive patterns of inheritance and are not autosomal dominant. Factor 10 deficiency (Option D) has both autosomal dominant and recessive inheritance but AD pattern of inheritance is less common in Factor 10 deficiency. Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page: 909, 910.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a complication of blood transfusion in a 25-year-old mother who developed acute postpartum haemorrhage (PPH), hypovolemic shock, and underwent major blood transfusion after delivering a baby boy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Hypokalemia Hypokalemia is not seen with blood transfusions. Instead, hyperkalemia occurs due to leakage of potassium from red blood cells in stored blood. Complications of Massive Blood Transfusion Complication Cause Effect Prevention/ Management Hypothermia (Option C) Transfusion of cold blood (stored at 4°C). Body temperature drops, leading to impaired clotting mechanisms (coagulopathy), and worsening bleeding. Warm blood products before transfusion Use external warming methods (e.g., warming blankets). Coagulopathy Dilution of clotting factors and platelets due to transfusion; consumption of clotting factors by ongoing haemorrhage. Impaired blood clotting, prolonged bleeding time, increased risk of continued bleeding. Administer fresh frozen plasma (FFP), platelets, and cryoprecipitate. For massive BT, blood products should be administered in a 1:1:1 ratio. Monitor clotting factors (e.g., PT, aPTT). Citrate Toxicity Large volumes of transfused blood contain citrate, which binds to calcium. Hypocalcemia (Option A) , leads to muscle cramps, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias. Administer calcium gluconate or calcium chloride prophylactically. Hyperkalemia (Option D) Potassium leaks from stored red blood cells into plasma during storage. Elevated potassium levels (hyperkalemia) can cause cardiac arrhythmias, potentially leading to cardiac arrest. Monitor potassium levels. Administer calcium to stabilize the myocardium. Insulin with glucose to shift potassium intracellularly if needed. Metabolic Alkalosis Rapid metabolism of citrate into bicarbonate. Increased pH (alkalosis) can lead to muscle twitching, irritability, and impaired oxygen release from haemoglobin. Monitor arterial blood gases (ABG) Adjust transfusion speed and, if necessary, reduce bicarbonate levels. Metabolic Acidosis Inadequate tissue perfusion leads to lactic acid accumulation. Lowered blood pH (acidosis) leads to confusion, fatigue, rapid breathing, and worsened cardiovascular function. Correct underlying cause (e.g., improve perfusion). Administer sodium bicarbonate in severe cases of acidosis. Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) Antibodies in transfused blood activate the recipient's immune response, causing inflammation and fluid buildup in the lungs. Non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema, presenting as acute respiratory distress with hypoxia within 6 hours of transfusion. Immediate cessation of transfusion. Oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation if necessary. Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO) The volume of transfused blood exceeds the patient’s capacity to manage, leading to fluid overload. Pulmonary oedema, shortness of breath, hypertension, and signs of heart failure. Administer diuretics (e.g., furosemide). Slow the rate of transfusion. Iron Overload Repeated transfusions lead to excessive accumulation of iron. Iron deposits in organs (e.g., liver, heart, pancreas), lead to organ damage and failure over time. Administer iron chelators (e.g., deferoxamine, deferasirox). Hemolytic Reactions ABO or Rh incompatibility. Rapid destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis), causes fever, chills, hemoglobinuria, and potentially acute renal failure or shock. Immediate cessation of transfusion. Supportive care

questions.question: Elective splenectomy is preferred in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C- Hereditary spherocytosis Hereditary spherocytosis is an inherited disorder characterized by abnormal red blood cells that are spherical in shape instead of the normal biconcave disc shape. Elective splenectomy is the primary treatment for Hereditary spherocytosis. In HS, splenectomy is particularly effective because the spleen is the primary site of spherocyte destruction. The timing of splenectomy varies with disease severity: severe HS requires elective splenectomy at 4-6 years of age, moderate HS can be delayed until puberty, while mild cases may be managed with folic acid supplementation alone. Management of Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS) Splenectomy as Primary Treatment Splenectomy significantly improves anemia by prolonging red cell survival, reducing the need for transfusions, and preventing iron overload and related organ damage. Post splenectomy: Spherocytosis and altered osmotic fragility persist, but reticulocyte counts and erythrocyte lifespan normalize. Blood Film Changes Post-Splenectomy Features like Howell-Jolly bodies , acanthocytes, target cells, cabot ring and Pappenheimer bodies appear after splenectomy. Indications for Splenectomy Recommended for patients with severe, transfusion-dependent anemia, growth failure, skeletal changes, leg ulcers, or extramedullary hematopoietic tumors. Timing of Splenectomy : Should be delayed until age 5–9 if possible or at least age 3, to reduce the risk of post-splenectomy sepsis while balancing the increased risk of gallstones in older children. Laparoscopic Splenectomy Preferred method, with benefits like less discomfort, quicker recovery, and shorter hospital stays. Combined laparoscopic splenectomy and cholecystectomy is an option for patients with symptomatic gallstones. Partial Splenectomy Used in infants or young children to alleviate anemia while preserving some splenic immune function. It reduces transfusion needs but may eventually require total splenectomy in about half of patients. Pre- and Post-Splenectomy Care Vaccination : Patients should receive vaccines against pneumococcus, Haemophilus influenzae type B, and meningococcus before surgery. Antibiotic Prophylaxis : Use of prophylactic antibiotics post-splenectomy is controversial but recommended by some for at least 5 years or even lifelong. Folic Acid : Continued supplementation (1 mg/day) is recommended to prevent folate deficiency. G6PD deficiency (Option A): In G6PD deficiency, splenectomy may actually worsen the anemia because the spleen filters and removes damaged red blood cells from the circulation. The primary management involves avoiding oxidative stressors and managing acute hemolytic episodes. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (Option B): In PNH, there is an abnormality in the complement system, and stem cell transplant is the best curative treatment. Splenectomy is not indicated as the hemolysis is complement-mediated and occurs throughout the circulation. Hairy cell leukemia (Option D): In hairy cell leukemia, chemotherapy is the standard treatment. Splenectomy may be considered only in cases with massively enlarged spleen or if there is resistance to other treatments, but it is not the preferred initial treatment option.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of Gaisböck syndrome?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A- Hypotension Gaisböck syndrome , primarily associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), is characterized by polycythemia secondary to chronic hypoxemia. The condition develops when the body responds to chronic hypoxemia by increasing erythropoietin production, leading to erythrocytosis. The patients with this syndrome typically present with elevated blood pressure rather than hypotension , due to the underlying respiratory disease and increased blood viscosity. Gaisböck syndrome Key Clinical Features High hematocrit levels Erythrocytosis (Option B Ruled Out) Normal leukocyte counts (Option C Ruled Out) No splenomegaly Hypertension Facial rubor Patient Characteristics Predominantly affects males Obese and anxious personality (Option D Ruled Out) Often cigarette smokers Risk Factors Alcoholism Diuretic therapy Physical & Emotional stress Obesity Smoking Pathophysiological Mechanisms Psychiatric disorders causing chronic stress Volume contraction (diuresis) Hypertension Nocturnal hypoxemia Increased erythropoietin production Complications Formation of microthrombi Cerebral infarction Vascular disease Treatment Approach Management of hypertension Weight reduction Smoking cessation Alcohol reduction/cessation Stress management Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8865286/

questions.question: What is the treatment for neutropenia following chemotherapy?
questions.explanation: (G-CSF) that stimulates the production of neutrophils. It is commonly used to treat neutropenia caused by chemotherapy by promoting the production of new neutrophils in the bone marrow. It is started one day after myelosuppressive chemotherapy and injected SC or IV, 5 µg/kg daily. Incorrect options: Option A - Leucovorin: Leucovorin is a medication that is used in combination with certain chemotherapy drugs to enhance their effectiveness. It is not specifically indicated for the treatment of neutropenia. Option C - Ondansetron: Ondansetron is an antiemetic medication used to prevent nausea and vomiting, particularly associated with chemotherapy or radiation treatment. It does not directly address neutropenia. Option D - Darbepoetin: Darbepoetin is a synthetic form of erythropoietin, a hormone that stimulates the production of red blood cells. It is used to treat anemia, but it does not have a direct effect on neutropenia. Reference: .

questions.question: Adhesion of platelets is the main function of von-willebrand factor. Which of the following is true for von-willebrand disease?
questions.explanation: caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor (VWF), a protein involved in platelet adhesion and the stabilization of factor VIII in the blood clotting cascade. Prothrombin time is not affected in von-willebrand disease as von-willebrand factor affects only the intrinsic factor. Incorrect options: Option A - "Normal partial thromboplastin time (PTT)": PTT is prolonged in von-willebrand disease as it does not bind to factor 8. Option B - "Decreased platelets": Von Willebrand disease does not directly affect platelet production or cause a decrease in platelet count. Platelet count is generally normal in VWD. Therefore, option B is incorrect. Option D - "Normal bleeding time": Since von Willebrand factor plays a crucial role in platelet adhesion, patients with VWD may have an increased bleeding time due to impaired platelet function. Therefore, option D is incorrect. Reference: .

questions.question: Which test is utilized for the diagnosis of DIC among the following options?
questions.explanation: D-dimer, a fibrin degradation product that is elevated in conditions associated with fibrin formation and breakdown, such as DIC. Elevated D-dimer levels indicate the activation of the clotting system and can support the diagnosis of DIC. Incorrect options: Option A - Fibrin degradation products is incorrect because while the presence of fibrin degradation products is a characteristic feature of DIC, the specific test used for their detection is the D-dimer assay. Option B - Activated partial thromboplastin time is incorrect because activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is a coagulation test that measures the intrinsic pathway of coagulation and is not specific to the diagnosis of DIC. Option C - Prothrombin time is incorrect because prothrombin time (PT) is a coagulation test that measures the extrinsic pathway of coagulation and is not specific to the diagnosis of DIC.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding polycythemia vera?

options.A: Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis
options.B: Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation
options.C: It is protective against H. Pylori infection
options.D: Acute myeloid leukaemia is the most common cause of mortality

questions.explanation: In polycythemia vera, a mutation in the JAK2 gene (JAK2 V617F mutation) is commonly observed. This mutation leads to the overactivation of certain cells, including mast cells, which release mediators that can cause generalized pruritus (itching) as a characteristic symptom of the disease. Other clinical features include high haemoglobin, or with symptoms of hyperviscosity, such as lassitude, loss of concentration, headaches, dizziness, blackouts, pruritus and epistaxis Incorrect Option: Option A - Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis: While polycythemia vera is associated with an increased risk of thrombosis, the degree of thrombocytosis alone does not strongly correlate with the risk.sk. Option C - It is protective against H. pylori infection: Polycythemia vera does not confer protection against Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection. Option D - Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality: While patients with polycythemia vera have an increased risk of developing acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and other myeloproliferative neoplasms, it is not the most common cause of mortality in polycythemia vera. Reference: .

questions.question: A patient of haemophilia received multiple blood transfusions. Which of the following metabolic abnormalities can be seen in a patient?
questions.explanation: transfusions, metabolic alkalosis can occur as a result of the citrate anticoagulant used in stored blood products. Citrate toxicity causes raised pH leading to redistribution of potassium eventually causing metabolic alkalosis. questions.question: What would be the most appropriate course of action for managing a patient presenting with fatigue, a haemoglobin level below 9 g/dl, and sickle-shaped red blood cells on peripheral smear examination?
